titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the International Association of Bridge, Structural, and Ornamental Iron Workers, Local 0580 Records WAG.214
titlestmt.author: Daniel Michelson and Gail Malmgreen, 2010

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-07-19 14:05:21 -0400.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.unittitle: International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers, Local 580 Records

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers. Local 580 (New York, N.Y.)

origination.label: source
origination.corpname: International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers. Local 580 (New York, N.Y.)

did.abstract: The International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers, Local 580 (Ornamental and Architectural Iron Workers) was chartered in 1938, evidently as a result of the restructuring of an older local, Local 447; its members traditionally did non-structural iron work, for example, construction of stairs, trap doors, metal walls, fire escapes, metal cabinets and furniture and ornamental details. The New York iron workers' organization claimed to be the oldest in the trade, and was at one time affiliated with the Knights of Labor; its members worked on the Statue of Liberty and many other historic projects. Originally dominated by German, Jewish and Irish craftsmen, the local's membership became more diverse by the 1980s, as a result of court orders regarding affirmative action. The collection includes correspondence, financial records, subject files, reports, membership applications and withdrawals and court documents relating to Equal Employment Opportunity Commission findings and directives, photographs, ephemera, and artifacts.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers, Local 580 (Ornamental and Architectural Iron Workers) was chartered in 1938, evidently as a result of the restructuring of an older local, Local 447; its members traditionally did non-structural iron work, for example, construction of stairs, trap doors, metal walls, fire escapes, metal cabinets and furniture and ornamental details. The New York iron workers' organization claimed to be the oldest in the trade, and was at one time affiliated with the Knights of Labor; its members worked on the Statue of Liberty and many other historic projects. Originally dominated by German, Jewish and Irish craftsmen, the local's membership became more diverse by the 1980s, as a result of court orders regarding affirmative action.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been processed by an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection includes correspondence, financial records, subject files, reports, membership applications and withdrawals and court documents relating to Equal Employment Opportunity Commission findings and directives, photographs, ephemera, and artifacts.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers, local 580 were transferred to New York University in 2001 by Dennis Lusardi. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Archives. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu, (212) 998-2630.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Dennis Lusardi, on behalf of the International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers, local 580, in 2001. The accession number associated with this gift is 2001.200.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers, Local 580 Records; WAG 214; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Photographs, ephemera, and artifacts from this collection were established as a separate collection, International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers, Local 580 Photographs (PHOTOS 133). In December 2013 these materials were reincorporated into the International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers, Local 580 Records (WAG 214).

Photographs: Black and White Prints of the Construction of the Singer Sewing Machine Building at Broadway and Liberty Street, New York CIty

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: These prints are reproductions from a book, newspaper, or other printed material that was probably published not long after the completion of construction of the Singer Sewing Machine Building (1908).

did.unittitle: Photographs: Copy Negatives of Prints of the Construction of the Singer Sewing Machine Building at Broadway and Liberty Street, New York CIty

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: These copy negatives were shot from a book, newspaper, or other printed material that was probably published not long after completion of construction of the Singer Sewing Machine Building (1908). All or most of the photographic prints located in Folder 1 in Box A005 of the records of the International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers, Local 580 (WAG 214) were printed from this group of negatives.

did.unittitle: Ephemera and Artifacts: Stickers and Pins with Local 580 Logo or Logos and Slogans of Other Labor Unions
